item.title: Covid: Indian variant cases in 86 council areas - Hancock
item.description: It's not just Bolton and Blackburn, says the health secretary, as he urges people to get vaccinated.

item.title: Thousands head off for overseas holidays
item.description: Holidaymakers from England, Scotland and Wales are now able to jet off for some early summer sun.

item.title: Israel-Gaza violence: Calls to protect civilians as conflict endures
item.description: The UN, US and UK are among those making calls for people caught in continuing, intense violence.

item.title: Covid: More than 6,000 vaccinated in Bolton over variant
item.description: Thousands of people got jabs in Bolton over the weekend as the town battles the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid-19: Indian variant cases up by 1,000, as surge vaccination picks up pace
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday evening.

item.title: Babes in the Wood: Killer's ex-girlfriend guilty of perjury
item.description: Jennifer Johnson faces jail after being convicted of lying in Russell Bishop's 1987 trial.

item.title: Sarah Everard: Met Police officers investigated over case file access
item.description: Officers who access records without a legitimate reason could be breaking the law, the Met says.

item.title: Bill Gates left Microsoft amid affair investigation
item.description: Microsoft has said that it investigated Mr Gates' attempt in 2000 "to initiate an intimate relationship".

item.title: New emergency text alerts to be trialled
item.description: A warning system will tested to advise people in areas affected by floods, fires, terror attacks or industrial incidents.

item.title: Holidaying Brits touch down in Portugal: 'It feels unreal'
item.description: Leisure travel from England, Scotland and Wales, to a select number of countries, is now allowed.

item.title: Pembrokeshire school bus crash: Car driver dies and 17 children hurt
item.description: Two of the 17 children hurt in Monday morning's school bus crash were taken to hospital.

item.title: School protests force U-turn after sick pupil banned from wearing cap
item.description: Pupils wearing caps and hoodies gather outside a school in support of Ella Goodwin on Monday.

item.title: In pictures: Lockdown eases in parts of the UK
item.description: Images from the day, as coronavirus rules are eased in England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Covid: Bingo is 'biggest thing I've missed in lockdown'
item.description: Amid the joy of being back there are fears that some customers may have died during lockdown.

item.title: 'Really moving' to perform first post-lockdown comedy show
item.description: Comedian Barry Ferns put on a show as soon as lockdown rules were eased at one minute past midnight.

item.title: 'Slow motion' avalanche on Ben Nevis
item.description: A group of extreme skiers had an unusual encounter with a "slow motion" avalanche on Ben Nevis.

item.title: The cost of calling out a 'rape joke'
item.description: One Malaysian teenager has braved a backlash for her principled stand.

item.title: The Passenger: Lost German novel makes UK bestseller list 83 years on
item.description: A novel written by a Jewish author in 1938 after he escaped Nazi Germany is climbing the book charts.

item.title: Eurovision 2021: Behind the scenes at this year's competition
item.description: Newsbeat looks at how this year's competition has been able to go ahead, in the face of Covid.

item.title: Lebanon in free-fall: 'For me, the country now is a large jail'
item.description: With the local currency losing 85% of its value, Lebanon's economy is disintegrating.

item.title: Israel-Gaza: Why is the region blurry on Google Maps?
item.description: High-resolution images of Israel and Gaza are available, so why not via public mapping tools?

item.title: How to deal with social anxiety with new-found freedom
item.description: The new-found freedoms for England, Scotland and Wales can be tough for those with anxiety.

item.title: Covid-19: YouTube launches vaccination ad campaign
item.description: The video-sharing site will pay for ads on buses, billboards and its own site to promote vaccination.

item.title: Belgian ambassador's wife claims diplomatic immunity over Seoul slap
item.description: The wife of Belgium's ambassador to South Korea is seen slapping a shop worker in CCTV footage.

item.title: Alisson scores winner: 'A monumental moment that could define Liverpool's season' - Danny Murphy
item.description: Former Liverpool midfielder Danny Murphy says Alisson's injury-time winner against West Brom means something positive has finally happened for Liverpool this season, and in an amazing way.

item.title: The Papers: 'Don't blow it, Britain' as nations 'open up'
item.description: The relaxation of lockdown rules, plus the warnings to remain "cautious", dominate Monday's papers.

item.title: Telling the tales of the northwest Highlands
item.description: New documentary explores what life is like for people in remote Scotland.

item.title: Eurovision 2021: How this year's acts are aiming for a Covid-safe contest
item.description: The acts of this year's Eurovision have been navigating a global pandemic to take part in Rotterdam.

item.title: Property in Wales: Buying a home 'unachievable' for many
item.description: Nearly half the homeowners helped by the Help to Buy scheme earn at least Â£40,000, a report says.

item.title: Lockdown easing: How to socialise without breaking the bank
item.description: If your bank balance is looking anything but healthy right now, this might help.

item.title: 'My exhausting smear test battle'
item.description: Transgender men, such as Laurie, are not automatically contacted for potentially life-saving smear tests.

item.title: Why is Huawei still in the UK?
item.description: Huawei defends its links with British universities, says it admires UK innovation

item.title: The app that lets you pay to control another person's life
item.description: NewNew aims to connect artists with their fans who can vote on aspects of their work and daily life.

item.title: Films, exhibitions and more things you can now see
item.description: Indoor entertainment venues in many areas can now reopen, so what's on and how will they work?

item.title: Eurovision winner Salvador Sobral says contest is history for him
item.description: Eurovision's highest-scoring winner Salvador Sobral says he now has to go his own way and set new goals.

item.title: Nigeria's Boko Haram militants: Six reasons they have not been defeated
item.description: After more than a decade of fighting, the Islamist militant group is still causing havoc in the north-east.

item.title: How do you convince people to have babies?
item.description: As China and the US look set to shrink in population, what can they do to encourage people to procreate?

item.title: Down's syndrome campaigner Heidi Crowter on marriage and loving life
item.description: Heidi Crowter is fighting for equality in the abortion law relating to Down's syndrome.

item.title: Danjuma gives Bournemouth first-leg win over Brentford
item.description: Bournemouth take a 1-0 lead over Brentford from their Championship play-off semi-final first leg thanks to Arnaut Danjuma's goal.

item.title: Reform petition calling for independent regulator in English football passes 100,000 signatures
item.description: A parliamentary petition calling for an independent regulator in English football passes 100,000 signatures

item.title: Man Utd players affected by protests - Solskjaer
item.description: Manchester United players have been affected by the fan protests about the club's ownership, according to manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

item.title: Tears, fury & broken bones: that'll be the Giro d'Italia's first week done, then
item.description: BBC Sport takes a look at the biggest talking points from the opening stages of the Giro d'Italia.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions have eased in England, Scotland and Wales

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: In some parts of the UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant from India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Which countries are on the green list for travel?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible from 17 May, but there are still rules in place.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to make hugging safer, from the experts
item.description: Millions of people will be able to hug loved ones again from Monday. But can you minimise the risk?

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: India variant: Why was India not put on the red list sooner?
item.description: India was put on the travel ban list two weeks after Pakistan and Bangladesh.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel through two south London boroughs are being urged to take a Covid-19 test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 38 and 39 in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Indian variant: What's causing the spike in Bolton?
item.description: The town has seen a sharp spike in Covid cases - driven by the emergence of the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 36 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the plans for the NHS app?
item.description: People travelling abroad from England will be able to use the NHS app to prove their Covid vaccination status.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Why we are doing this
item.description: The experts behind our project explain why the BBC is looking at the impact of climate change on sport.

item.title: A World Cup like no other?
item.description: Games lasting an hour and fans around the world watching in virtual reality? BBC Sport imagines what a 2050 World Cup in China might look like in the face of climate change.

item.title: Quiz: How are sports battling climate change?
item.description: See how much you know about the environmental "good guys" of sport.

item.title: A weather forecast from the future
item.description: What do conditions look like in 2050 for major sporting venues? BBC weather forecaster Simon King explains...

item.title: Cricket beneath the dome
item.description: Is a bio-dome the saviour of summer cricket? BBC Sport imagines a new world of indoor cricket - and how players and fans might react.

item.title: Uyghur imams targeted in China's Xinjiang crackdown
item.description: China has targeted Muslim religious leaders, according to a new report, charging many with extremism.

item.title: 'Talk to me': A train driver asking men to open up
item.description: A tragedy inspired Scotland's only woman freight train driver to get men talking about mental health.

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.

item.title: The 'smart and cheeky' Aboriginal boy teaching Australia a lesson
item.description: A film about an Aboriginal boy's experience of school shines a light on Australia's failure to give all children a fair start.

item.title: Joe Ligon: America's 'longest juvenile lifer' on 68 years in prison
item.description: After waiting seven decades for freedom, Joe Ligon tells the BBC how he intends to spend the rest of his days.
